content: Away, beyond the sea line, invisible, lay Palm Tree, an island beautiful as a dream, yet swarming with devils. Little Tari, the son of Le Taioi the net maker, sitting on the coral close by, looked up at him. Tari knew little of life, but he knew that all the men of Karolin swept away by war had left the women and the boys and the children like himself defenseless, without a man or leader. Then, yesterday, from the northern sea in a strange boat and with Katafa, the girl who had been blown to sea years ago when out fishing, this strange new figure had come, sent by the gods, so the women said, to be their chief and ruler. The child knew nothing of who the gods might be, nor did he care. Alone now with this wonderful new person, and out of earshot of his mother, he put the question direct with all the simplicity of childhood. “Taori,” little Tari said, “who are you?” (é kamina tai) Could Dick have answered, would the child have understood the strange words
author: writer_agent
